greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: n is the a(n)-th positive integer having its digitsum.
comment: Ordinal transform of A007953. - _Antti Karttunen_, May 20 2017
link: David A. Corneth, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: 35 is the 4th positive integer having digitsum 8 (the others before are 8, 17 and 26) so a(35) = 4.
mathematica: c[n_, k_] := If[n >= k, Binomial[n, k], 0]; b[s_, q_, n_] := (s1 = q; If[s <= q*(n - 1), s1 = s + q; Sum[(-1)^i*c[q, i]*c[s1 - 1 - n*i, q - 1], {i, 0, q - 1}], 0]); a[n_] := (r = 1; v = IntegerDigits[n]; l = v[[-1]]; For[i = Length[v] - 1, i >= 1, i--, For[j = 1, j <= v[[i]], j++, r += b[l + j, Length[v] - i, 10]]; l += v[[i]]]; r); Table[a[n], {n, 1, 110}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 14 2016, adapted from PARI *)
program: \\ways to roll s-q with q dice having sides 0 through n - 1.
a(n)={r = 1; v=digits(n); l=v[#v]; forstep(i = #v-1, 1, -1, for(j=1,v[i], r+=b(l+j, #v-i,10)); l+=v[i]);r}
f x m = y : f (x + 1) (insert q (y + 1) m) where
y = findWithDefault 1 q m; q = a007953 x
xref: Cf. A286478 (analogous sequence for factorial base).
results.author: _David A. Corneth_, Jan 31 2015
